by default

tired, stressed... so, pretty good, thanks. you?

So part of the discussion we need to have is about what data formats we want to be supporting and how
1. Whatever we do here is going to impact the discussion around the XSLT engine later on — if we're about to discuss what I think is coming up (JSON & JSONP) then it's going to have a big impact
Welcome all, thanks for dropping in
heh
First things first, let's take a couple of minutes to hash out why we're here

I believe part of the motivation is that Symphony presently has a heavy XML dependency, and as the web begins to shift away from XML (at least to some degree), we need to be thinking about how we adapt
Allen's about 30 minutes away from home, so I'd like us to focus on the first of those two questions for now
Not really — they both seem like fairly broad topics
I might be thinking in circles a little bit
and I think we want to talk about what parts of the system this needs to touch

but XML to JSON is not easy at all

great

About the same :) I screwed up a quote a few weeks back, and didn't realise until I was halfway through the job. So yeah — tired, stressed — but life it good, I can't complain :)

I have a couple of thoughts around this:
Don't believe so, not that I know of
Right. So I think it would behoove us to come off as JSON-friendly in the same way that we are XML-friendly. What would that mean?
Sorry, Allen just called, he lost connectivity
sorry
Can you explain a little more what you mean by that?

OK — reset. So the motivator for this topic really comes back to what we were talking about the other week, right Craig? The fact that XSLT is essentially on life support if you're not a Java platform — and if we're going to think about throwing XSLT out, we should think about what our underlying data output format is as well. Am I right?
Dynamic JSON datasources would be simple to write
@buzzomatic PHP has support for JSON output natively now, right?
S3 will have to be XSLT.
Agreed.
Yeah
I was aiming at letting people say "I want symphony to take the data model I've created, and the data source I've defined and output it directly in CSV, or SuperNewNotInventedFileFormat"
so building one is different than building the other
Are we ranging too far from what's realistic for S3 with a full data output rejig like this?
right
Sure
Anybody have anything to add?
Maybe just dive in?
I think it's a little too early to think about an alternative to xslt for s3
Right
Which I'm pretty sure there's not — as nice as Dusty looks on paper ;)
it's not inconceivable, however, to have the system be a little more abstracted, a little more extensible, so that an extension could allow views to output JSON and template it some other way
So... what we've got now is a system that builds XML little by little as it processes each request, and then at the end it takes that and runs an XSLT transformation
ok, so we're talking about a full-on data output API that extensions could tap into to provide these alternative output modes
(hi guys. going to lurk a bit...)
Good to know

Partly so. To be honest, I'm not entirely sure what folks had in mind when they raised "support for other data formats" in the visioning exercise. But my take on it is influenced by that realization, that at the moment XSLT appears to not have a very strong future on the web
What happens to attributes?
the problem is that XML and JSON don't map one-to-one
I think we need to have a decision on XSLT or something else. This will inform us on how to approach this.
2. Has anyone done any research around upcoming web data formats
LOL — bye Allen in preparation :P
we're talking about building in more under-the-hood flexibility
I did a quick whip around tonight, and nothing is really sticking out at me aside from JSON as "up and coming" — and JSON's already here
I think we need to approach the core in a way that accommodates an alternative template layer should that happen in the future
Is it worth thinking about allowing an extensible output switch on the view?
json_encode/json_decode
What about XML -> PHP Obj -> JSON?
I've not had to do that before
OT: http://akdubya.github.com/dustjs/
Okay so we have a direction and a view on how to scope the data format in s3

Agreed
@czheng yes, I think so — but in a way that's extensible for future data formats
Yep

Yeah, I wouldn't mess with that for S3 — unless there's a good, viable alternative we can use now
yeah

#1 Traditional symphony: XML for passing to XSLT processor
Wrt output, the dissonance between related sections can be better handled
I hadn't considered that at all
also, to be clear, despite all these shifts the idea is that for the most part S3 would behave very much like S2 by default, in terms of output and templating
it's certainly very ambitious
It would be nice to abstract the data model from the data output/presentation in a way that symphony developers (not WG/core team developers) could have some more control over
@allen I agree — but I'm trying to understand the motivation behind any change we might make here
So if we're thinking about future proofing here, it's worth thinking about re-building a data output API?
Reworking the way data is output to be less dependent on XML structures and basically hand off the encoding to a data extension class
Provide alternative output formats, yeah

:D
Rather than pushing it via a templating engine — but that'll negate a lot of the niceties of what we have

dynamic ds types can handle parsing whatever format

one implication of that would be that View Templates have to be decoupled from Views
like... if the mode is XML, then all the method calls will result in DOMElements

Yeah, so that's going into our proposal... approaching the core in a way that leaves open the possibility of other templating layers

or decoupled from XSLT
No drop ins

So right now, Symphony is completely tied to XML for data output — how deep does the integration go?
instead of building XML for output, can we assemble PHP objects and provide an API for accessing those? and then the default 'mode' would turn them into XML?
I'd think it best to leave the specifics to whoever implements and just provide high-level goals with some thinking around implications and considerations like performance, memory reqs, APIs, etc
